Although this course of action is in large part dictated
by the slow development of OTP, by no means should the JCET
abandon its support of UIIF television as the only presently
visible source of additional channels necessary for an adequate
national TV system. Indeed, ETV has given strong support to
and shown its faith in UHF by the construction and operation of
UHF stations in such cities as Cincinnati* Columbus, Detroit,
Philadelphia, Atlanta and Madison, despite the discouraging
prospects in terms of UHF conversion. Furthermore, ETV is now
turning to UHF for additional educational service in Pittsburgh}
and the same may soon be true in several other cities such as
Oklahoma City where a single ETV facility is proving insufficient
to meet the variety of needs that have developed. It is entirely
probable that the utilization of the UHF reservations in New York
and Los Angeles, and perhaps elsewhere, is dependent upon the
prior establishment of a VHF educational facility*
But what is now most needed for a sound national ETV
structure is a program of action that will provide VHF coverage
in the large cities already mentioned * The JCET will, not be
alone in moving in this direction. Already the initiative has
been taken locally in New York, Detroit, Rochester and East
Lansing. But the possibilities open in these cities are not
available in most of the other "white areas
